Transfer hydrogenation of anisole in 2-PrOH has been studied as a model reaction for lignocellulose processing. The reaction was studied over high-loaded Ni-based catalysts synthesized via supercritical antisolvent precipitation of a Ni precursor and sols of four oxides: Al2O3, SiO2, TiO2, and ZrO2. It was demonstrated that the oxide support significantly affects the structure of the catalysts, their activity, and selectivity. The best performance in the transfer hydrodeoxygenation of anisole was shown by Ni supported on alumina at 250 °C, which was explained by the highest dispersion of Ni0 particles in this catalyst and by the highest concentration of acid centers. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Transfer hydrogenation Supercritical antisolvent precipitation Anisole Ni-based catalysts Supercritical 2-PrOH 1 Introduction Climate changes, pollution, and depletion of non-renewable resources demand the development of alternative energy processes and methods. Within this paradigm, biomass is considered as the main source of various organic compounds [1,2]; however, its conversion to fuel or fine chemicals is a complicated process due to the presence of many aromatic groups and high oxygen content. For example, lignin, one of the main components of lignocellulose, can contain up to 40 wt% of oxygen [3,4], mostly connected directly to the aromatic ring [2]. Thus, hydrodearomatization (HDA) and hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) are the key routes of biomass conversion [1,5]. Lignin and products of its depolymerization include many alkoxybenzenes; therefore, anisole and some other molecules, such as phenol or guaiacol, are usually used as prototypes [5–7]. Supported Ni-based catalysts are among the most commonly used for the hydrotreatment of fast pyrolysis liquid [8,9]. It has been found that their catalytic performance can be significantly enhanced due to certain properties of the support. In this regard, the key role of support acidity is emphasized in many studies. For example, Jin et al. [10] analyzed the selectivity of conventional hydrogenation of anisole over Ni catalysts supported on oxides or activated carbon. They found that nickel supported on oxides was active in both HDA and HDO, whereas the use of a neutral carbon support led to small amounts of deoxygenated products. The importance of high acidity of the support was also demonstrated for the HDO of anisole over Ni supported on SAPO-11 and SBA-15 [11]. In other studies, it has been found that there is a correlation between the deoxygenation rate and the number of strong acid centers [12]. In addition, it was shown that Ni-based catalysts supported on carbon with strong acid sites provide fast deoxygenation of anisole. The authors also noted that small nickel particles facilitate the formation of benzene, whereas the larger ones contribute to the formation of cyclohexane or even n-hexane. This result agrees well with the data obtained for the gas-phase HDO of m-cresol over Ni/SiO2 [13]. It was demonstrated that acid centers facilitate the adsorption of phenolic compounds via the interaction with oxygen-containing groups that provide their further transformations [14,15]. In the last few years, some alternative, H2-free routes of chemical reduction have been widely studied [5,16,17]. At that, lower aliphatic alcohols are considered as one of the most promising H-donors, which can also be produced from biomass [17–19]. Ni-based catalysts supported on oxides demonstrate excellent results in the transfer hydrogenation (TH) of biomass-derived compounds, as well as in the conventional reduction. For instance, a Ni/CeO2 catalyst was used for the hydrogenation of phenolic compounds with secondary alcohols [20]. Hengne et al. demonstrated that levulinic acid is reduced to γ-valerolactone with Ni supported on SiO2, Al2O3, and ZnO, using 2-PrOH as an H-donor [21]. In another study, Ni/Al2O3 and 2-PrOH were used for C-O hydrogenolysis in aryl ethers [22]. The transformations of furfural were studied by Wang et al. using Ni-based catalysts supported on activated carbon and 2-PrOH as a solvent and an H-donor [23]. In our previous study, we demonstrated the activity of Raney® nickel in the TH of anisole with 2-PrOH [24]. The performance of Raney® nickel in the TH of phenolic compounds was studied by Ferrini et al. in details [16]. In contrast to the supported Ni-based catalysts, the high-loaded and unsupported ones, including Raney® nickel, can be effectively used for the TH at lower temperatures [25–27]. However, the low thermal stability of Raney® nickel catalysts makes their regeneration impossible, which significantly limits their practical applications. Traditional approaches to the synthesis of Ni-containing catalysts, which are based on impregnation [28], co-precipitation [29], deposition-precipitation [30], sol-gel technologies [31], etc., often lead to the formation of nitrate-containing wastes, whose thermal decomposition results in the emission of dangerous nitrogen oxides. Accordingly, the development and implementation of new green approaches to the synthesis of heterogeneous catalysts will make the biomass conversion more environmentally friendly, not only in terms of obtaining the product, but also in terms of providing the complete technological cycle. One of the alternative and actively developed approaches to carrying out various chemical processes is the use of supercritical fluid (SCF) technologies [19,32]. These methods can be applied to produce tetraalkyl silicates [33], aerogel-containing composites [34], membranes for gas separation [35], etc. One of the promising SCF approaches to the synthesis of heterogeneous catalysts and other functional materials is Supercritical AntiSolvent (SAS) precipitation [36]. This method makes it possible to avoid the use of nitrates to obtain active multicomponent catalysts of a mixed structure without phase separation. For example, this method was used to synthesize a mixed copper and zinc hydroxocarbonate with the structure of georgeite [37,38]. A catalyst obtained from this hydroxycarbonate exhibited high activity in methanol production [37] and in the water gas shift reaction [38]. Recently, we have developed an original method for the synthesis of bimetallic catalysts based on the joint SAS coprecipitation of stable oxide sols [27] and the addition of water as a co-solvent to avoid phase separation [39]. The oxide sols in this case formed a stabilizing matrix and made it possible to obtain highly dispersed metal catalysts [40] and various functional nanomaterials [41,42]. Using this method, we synthesized a series of Ni-Cu catalysts with the structure of NixCu1−x substitutional solid solution [43]. These catalysts were successfully tested in the hydrodeoxygenation of anisole, as a model compound for bio-oil, and the Ni87Cu13 catalyst showed the highest activity. In this work, we used this original and environmentally friendly method for the synthesis of high-loaded Ni-based catalysts, and tested them in the transfer hydrogenation of anisole. The aim of this work was to compare the effect of different oxide supports (Al2O3, SiO2, TiO2, and ZrO2) on both catalyst properties and their activity in anisole transformations. For this, the catalysts were thoroughly characterized, and a kinetic model of anisole transformations was analyzed. The experiments were carried out in the liquid phase (150 °C) and under supercritical conditions (250 °C) in 2-PrOH as a solvent and a hydrogen donor. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Reagents The following reagents have been used: anisole (99 %, Sigma-Aldrich), dodecane (≥99 %, Sigma-Aldrich), 2-PrOH (≥99.5 %, Sigma-Aldrich), nickel acetate (Ni(OAc)2·4H2O, (99 % extra, Acros Organics), methanol (J.T. Barker, HPLC Gradient Grade), CO2 (99.8 %, Promgazservis, Russia), tetraethoxysilane (TEOS, 98 %, Acros Organics), aluminum tri-sec-butoxide (97 %, Acros Organic), zirconium (IV) propoxide (70 wt% solution in propanol, Acros Organic), and titanium (IV) isopropoxide (98 %, Acros Organics). 2.2 Catalyst synthesis The Ni-containing catalysts were synthesized by supercritical antisolvent coprecipitation using a specially designed SAS-50 setup (Waters, USA). A methanol solution containing nickel acetate and oxide sol was injected into a stream of supercritical carbon dioxide. This led to a decrease in the solvent power of the carbon dioxide-methanol mixture, and precipitation occurred. After that, pure CO2 was passing through the obtained powder for 20 min to remove a residual solvent. A detailed description of the synthesis technique is given elsewhere [44]. The experimental parameters were as follows: a CO2 flow was 80 g/min, a solution flow was 2 ml/min, temperature was 40 °C, a nozzle diameter was 0.004″ (0.1016 mm), and a pressure was 150 bar. The total concentration of Ni(OAc)2.4 H2O was 35.7 mg/ml for all samples. The concentration of sol oxide was chosen to obtain the samples with 50 wt% oxide in the reduced metal catalyst. The typical volume of methanol solution was 120 ml. Using four different sols (SiO2, TiO2, Al2O3, and ZrO2), we obtained four catalysts, which were respectively designated as Ni_Sil, Ni_Tit, Ni_Alum, and Ni_Zirc. After coprecipitation, the samples were calcined at 300 °C for 3 h with a ramp rate 3 °C/min in static air to form an oxide phase. The Ni_Sil, Ni_Tit, and Ni_Zirc catalysts were reduced in an Н2 flow (30 ml/min) at 450 °C for 45 min with a ramp rate 3 °C/min. The Ni_Alum catalyst was reduced at 650 °C without changing other parameters. For characterization, the catalysts were thoroughly passivated in air. Synthesis of SiO2 sol: to prepare partially hydrolyzed TEOS, the following three reagents were successively added to 20 ml of TEOS: 15 ml of methanol, 2.2 ml of water, and 0.3 ml of 0.1 N HCl. The resulting solution was left under stirring for 24 h. For the complete hydrolysis, distilled water was added to the resulting partially hydrolyzed solution in a ratio of 0.3 ml of water per 1 ml of the solution and left to mix for 1 h. After that, the SiO2 sol (9.1 ml) was diluted with methanol to 120 ml. Synthesis of Al2O3 sol: under constant stirring, 4 ml of acetylacetone was added to 38 ml of isopropanol, and then 5 ml of aluminum-tri-sec-butoxide was added to this solution. After addition of aluminum-tri-sec-butoxide, a white precipitate was formed. Then, 70 ml of methanol was added to the suspension. After 15 min of stirring, the precipitate dissolved, and 2.82 ml of water was added into the resulting solution. The solution was left under stirring for 24 h. Synthesis of TiO2 sol: under constant stirring, 2.86 ml of acetic acid was added to 111.6 ml of methanol, followed by 3.75 ml of titanium isopropoxide (70 % solution in isopropanol). After 15 min of stirring, 1.8 ml of water was added into the solution. This solution was left under stirring for 24 h. Synthesis of ZrO2 sol: under constant stirring, 1.67 ml of acetylacetone was added to 113.5 ml of methanol, followed by 3.64 ml of zirconium propoxide (70 % solution in isopropanol). After 15 min of stirring, 1.17 ml of water was added into the resulting solution. The solution was left under stirring for 24 h. After the synthesis, each sol had the volume of 120 ml and contained 1 g of the corresponding oxide. 2.3 Catalyst characterization 2.3.1 XRD The XRD measurements were carried out using a D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer (Bruker, Germany) equipped with a Lynxeye linear detector. The XRD patterns were measured using the Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) in the 2θ range of 10°−75° with a step of 0.05° and accumulation time of 3 s at each point. The XRD phase analysis was performed using the ICDD PDF-4 + database. The TOPAS software was used for the analysis of peak profiles and for the Rietveld refinement. The mean size of coherently scattering regions or crystallites (DXRD) was estimated by the line broadening analysis according to the Scherrer equation. The instrumental broadening was determined from the XRD pattern of a standard reference material (silicon). 2.3.2 ICP-AES Inductively coupled plasma–atomic emission spectroscopy (Perkin–Elmer Optima 4300-DV) was used to determine the elemental composition of the catalysts. 2.3.3 N2 adsorption An ASAP-2400 automated volumetric adsorption analyzer (Micromeritics Instrument. Corp., USA) was used to determine the texture characteristics of the catalysts. The samples were dried under vacuum at room temperature and then replaced into a special cell under inert (argon) atmosphere. After degassing at 300 °C and residual pressure of 0.13 Pa for 7 h, adsorption isotherms were measured at the liquid nitrogen temperature (−196 °C). The surface area (SBET) of the samples was determined by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller method. 2.3.4 NH3-TPD The acidic strength of the samples was analyzed by the temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) using an Autosorb-1 apparatus (Quantachrome Instruments) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. First, a sample was saturated with NH3 at 100 °C for 30 min. Then, physically adsorbed ammonia was desorbed from the sample in a He flow (25 ml/min) at 120 °C for 30 min. The desorption of chemically adsorbed ammonia was started by increasing the temperature from 120 °C to 500 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. 2.3.5 CO pulse chemisorption The CO pulse chemisorption was measured using a Chemosorb analyzer equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. Before the experiment, 50 mg of each catalyst was placed in a U-shape quartz reactor and treated in an H2 flow (100 ml/min) upon heating. The samples supported on SiO2, TiO2, and ZrO2 were heated to 450 °C, and the sample supported on Al2O3 was heated to 650 °C. The reactor was kept at the final temperature for 20 min and then purged with an inert gas (Ar), followed by cooling to room temperature. After that, pulses of CO were fed to the reactor (100 µL) until the amount of CO in the outlet stopped changing. Thereafter the amount of chemisorbed CO was estimated. 2.3.6 HRTEM The morphology and microstructure of the catalysts were studied using high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM). The images were obtained using a Themis Z electron microscope (Thermo Fisher Scientific, The Netherlands) equipped with a Ceta 16 CCD sensor and a corrector of spherical aberrations, which provided a maximum lattice resolution of 0.07 nm at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The microscope was also equipped with an EDX Super-X spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, The Netherlands) with a semiconductor Si detector providing an energy resolution of 128 eV. The samples for the HRTEM study were deposited on a perforated carbon film mounted on an aluminum grid by the ultrasonic dispersal of the catalyst suspension in ethanol. 2.4 Batch experiments Before the experiment, each oxidized catalyst (0.42–0.43 g for the experiments at 150 °C or 0.12 g for the experiments at 250 °C) was reduced in an H2 flow (30 l/h) for 45 min. The reduction was carried out in a quartz tube at 450 °C for the catalysts supported on ZrO2, TiO2, and SiO2 and at 650 °C for the catalyst supported on Al2O3. After that, the samples were cooled to room temperature, purged with Ar, and carefully transferred to a beaker filled with 30 ml of 2-PrOH. The suspension from the beaker was loaded into a batch reactor (Hastelloy c276, 285 ml) preliminary purged with Ar. Then, a solution containing 3.2 g of anisole (29.6 mmol), 0.25–0.26 g of dodecane (internal standard), and 80 ml of 2-PrOH was added to the reactor. After that, the reactor was purged with argon under stirring (with a mechanical agitator MagneDrive®). The reactor was closed and heated to 150 °C for 20 min or to 250 °C for 35 min. The reaction was carried out at a constant temperature with permanent stirring at 800 rpm. The self-pressure of the reaction mixture achieved 7.1–7.8 MPa at 250 °C and 0.7–1.0 MPa at 150 °C. During the experiment, the reaction mixture was periodically sampled for the analysis. To calculate the conversion of anisole and selectivities for HDA and HDO, the following equations were used: (1) Conve rsion = Anisole in − Anisole fin Anisole in × 100 % (2) HDO selectivity = ∑ Oxygen − free products ∑ All products × 100 % (3) HDA selectivity = ∑ Aromatic − free products ∑ All products × 100 % 2.5 Product analysis The liquid samples were analyzed using a Shimadzu GCMS–QP2010 SE chromato-mass spectrometer equipped with an autosampler and with a GsBP-INOWAX capillary chromatographic column (crosslinked polyethylene glycol, a length of 30 m, an internal diameter of 0.32 mm, and a stationary phase thickness of 0.25 µm). The temperature mode of column conditioning was as follows: 55 °C for 3 min, heating to 200 °C at a rate of 15 °C/min, and then heating to 270 ⁰C at a rate of 25 ⁰C/min. The evaporator temperature was 270 °C, split 1:30, and helium was used as a carrier gas. A flow rate of the carrier gas was 1.8 ml/min. The products were identified using a peak retention time and mass spectra, which were compared with the data from the NIST and Wiley7 electronic mass spectral libraries or, in some cases, with corresponding data on pure compounds. The conversion of anisole and the yield of products were evaluated using dodecane as an internal standard. 2.6 Kinetic data analysis Experimentally obtained conversion of anisole was described by a quasi-first order kinetics with respect to anisole and intermediate products. A change in a molar fraction was calculated using the following simplified model: dC i /dt= k i C i , where k i is the first-order rate constant, and C i is the molar fraction of anisole and reaction products. The reaction rate constants were determined by the least-squares method using the obtained analytical solution. The following function was minimized: (4) F k → = ∑ i , j ( c ij exp − c i calc ( t j , k → ) ) 2 where k → is the vector of reaction rate constants, k → = (k 1, k 2, k 3, k 4, k 5, k 6); j is the serial number of an experimental point, t j is the time of a j-th point, c ij exp is the experimental molar fraction of an i-th component at time t j , c i calc ( t j , k → ) is the calculated molar fraction of the i-th component at time t j . The c i calc ( t j , k → ) concentrations were calculated using the Runge-Kutta method [45,46]. Turnover frequencies (TOF) were calculated as a ratio between the initial rate r 0 of anisole conversion (mol·s−1·gcat −1) and the number of sites n CO active in the CO uptake (molCO·gcat −1), which were determined by the CO chemisorption: TOF = r 0 CO uptake = k ∙ n 0 n CO where n 0 is the initial molar content of anisole in a solution (mol), and k is the observed total rate constant of anisole conversion determined from the kinetic studies (s−1). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization A detailed analysis of the processes that take place during the catalyst preparation can provide information that is crucial for understanding the formation mechanism and the structure of a catalyst. Thus, the information about the Ni-containing oxide precursors of the catalysts formed immediately after the calcination is quite significant. Fig. 1 shows XRD data for the oxide precursors before their reduction in H2. After calcination at 300 °C, all the samples exhibit the peaks related to the NiO phase (PDF № 047–1049). The mean size of NiO crystallites and some textural characteristics (such as surface area and pore volume) are provided in Table 1. In the case of the Ni_Tit sample, all the XRD peaks are the superposition of broad and sharp peaks. This indicates a coexistence of well and poorly crystallized NiO species. Hence, two crystallite sizes DXRD were determined for this sample. The Rietveld refined parameter of the NiO crystal lattice agrees with the characteristic value (a=4.177 Å). In the case of Ni_Alum, this parameter is significantly lower and equals only a= 4.149 Å. This fact can be explained by the formation of Ni and Al mixed oxide [47], that demonstrates a strong metal-support interaction in Ni_Alum. At the same time, the phases SiO2, Al2O3, TiO2 and ZrO2 were not found in the corresponding samples, which shows their X-ray amorphous state. Ni_Sil has the highest surface area SBET = 382 m2/g, whereas Ni/ZrO2 has only SBET = 142 m2/g. All textural characteristics of the calcined samples are provided in Table 1. Fig. 2 demonstrates the results of XRD analysis of the catalysts reduced in H2. As seen, the XRD pattern of Ni_Sil includes the peaks assigned only to metal Ni0 crystallites (PDF#00–004–0850), with the mean size of 13.0 nm. In the case of Ni_Alum, Ni0 crystallites are the smallest in the series and are equal to 5.5 nm. This sample also contains the NiO phase, which is likely formed during the passivation of Ni nanoparticles under air before the analysis. The mean size of Ni0 crystallites in Ni_Tit and Ni_Zirc is 10.0 nm and 11.5 nm, respectively. The Ni_Tit sample also contains polymorphic modifications of TiO2, namely the anatase phase (PDF#00–021–1272) and the rutile phase (PDF#00–021–1276). The Ni_Zirc sample can contain a metastable tetragonal (t-ZrO2, PDF #00–054–1089) and cubic (c-ZrO2, PDF#00–049–1642) phase of zirconium dioxide. However, the strong broadening of the peaks due to the high dispersion does not allow an unambiguous determination of the phase of zirconium dioxide. The parameter of the Ni0 crystal lattice for these samples is in the range of 3.523 – 3.525 Å, which is very close to the standard value a = 3.524 Å. The more detailed analysis of the phase composition is presented in Table 1. It is important to note that Ni_Alum was reduced at 650 °C. This temperature was chosen because the standard temperature 450 °C was not enough for its complete reduction. Indeed, the in situ XRD data (Fig. S1 in Supplementary materials) show that the complete reduction of the Ni_Alum catalyst proceeds only at 650 °C. Despite the significantly harder reduction conditions, Ni0 crystallites in Ni_Alum have the smallest mean crystallite size. Probably, this effect is associated with the strong metal-support interaction observed for this sample (Fig. 1), which prevents the sintering of nanosized Ni0 particles and, at the same time, hinders the reduction to the metal state. The acidity of all the reduced catalysts was determined by NH3 temperature-programmed desorption ( Fig. 3). The gaussian deconvolution of the whole TPD profiles, as well as the maximum of every desorption peak, is presented in Table 1. All the catalysts possess three main desorption peaks with the maximum at 154–189 °С (weak sites), 223–281 °С (medium sites), and 357–417 °С (strong sites). The highest total concentration of the acid centers (0.143 µmol/g) is observed for the Ni_Alum sample; however, Ni_Sil has the highest amount of the strong centers (0.050 µmol/g, at T = 365 °C). The samples of Ni_Tit and Ni_Zirc contain a lower amount of acidic groups on their surface, which is 0.070 µmol/g and 0.057 µmol/g, respectively. The reduction of catalysts at high temperature expectedly leads to a decrease in their surface area compared to that observed right after calcination (Table 1). The sintering is significant for the Ni_Sil, Ni_Tit, and Ni_Zirc samples – their surface area decreases by 1.7–4.2 times. However, this drop can also be affected by crystallization. As mentioned above, Ni on Al2O3 was reduced under the harder conditions at 650 °C; nevertheless, the decrease in its surface area was the least in the series. In addition, it is important to note that, in contrast to other oxides, the crystalline Al2O3 phase was not formed under these conditions (Fig. 2). The textural parameters of the samples reduced under H2 are shown in details in Table 1. The Ni content was determined by the ICP-AES method. As seen from Table 1, all the catalysts contain from 46.8 to 57.8 wt% of Ni. The highest metal content was observed for the Ni_Alum catalyst. This fact may be a consequence of the incomplete hydrolysis of aluminum-tri-sec-butoxide during the sol synthesis, which, accordingly, leads to a higher metal content in Ni_Alum catalyst. However, despite this, this catalyst exhibits the greatest dispersion of the metal phase. The number of metallic sites on the catalyst surface was measured by CO pulse chemisorption (Table 1). The highest CO uptake 381 µmol/g was obtained for Ni_Alum, which correlates with its small crystallite size (DXRD). The samples Ni_Tit and Ni_Zirc have similar crystallite sizes and can bind close amounts of CO (about 240 µmol/g). At the same time, Ni_Sil uptakes more carbon monoxide (297 µmol/g); however, the size of Ni0 crystallites in this sample is larger (according to XRD). This result may be associated with a more developed surface in Ni_Sil, which leads to a better accessibility of the metal surface for CO adsorption, as well as to the formation of small particles of metallic nickel (<3 nm), which are difficult to detect by the XRD method. The synthesized catalysts contain spherical porous agglomerates with the size from 50 to 300 nm (Fig. S2 , see Supplementary information). These agglomerates, in turn, are composed of smaller particles (from 5 to 10 nm) consisting of both metal nickel and oxide particles of the support. The analysis of EDX-mapping ( Fig. 4) demonstrates that the Ni_Sil and Ni_Zirc samples have a core-shell structure. Their catalyst surface is enriched with Ni nanoparticles, which is more obvious for Ni_Zirc. Based on the EDX-mapping data, it can also be concluded that the distribution of nickel in Ni_Alum catalyst has greater homogeneity in comparison with other support. Thus, EDX, as well as other methods, proves that Ni_Alum has finer Ni0 particles compared to other samples, although it has the highest reduction temperature. Thus, we can conclude that the oxide matrix significantly affects the formation of the catalysts and, as a result, its structure and properties. 3.2 Transfer hydrogenation of anisole Anisole was used as a model compound for oxygen-containing components of bio-oil [48] and other sources of hydrocarbons. The anisole molecule contains an O-CH3 group, which significantly decreases its reactivity compared to phenol and other molecules containing a free OH-group [20,49]. For example, De Castro et al. demonstrated that 1,2-dimethoxybenzene stayed almost stable at 80 °C with Raney® nickel and 2-PrOH as a hydrogen donor, whereas different methoxyphenols were converted into phenol, cyclohexanol, and its derivatives. The authors explained this results in terms of adsorption. In particular, they demonstrated that the free OH-group provides effective bonding with the catalyst surface. Similar results were demonstrated for a Ni/CeO2 catalyst used with secondary alcohols as hydrogen donors [20]. It was shown that, unlike phenol, guaiacol, and m-cresol, the anisole molecule, which does not have a free OH-group, was stable over Ni/CeO2. Thus, our efforts were focused on anisole, which exhibited a low reactivity under TH conditions. 2-PrOH, which demonstrated excellent activity in TH [17,19], was used as a solvent and H-donor. The alcohol was transformed into H2 and acetone, which were both found in reaction mixtures in significant amounts. Fig. 5 shows a scheme of anisole transformations under TH conditions in the presence of the catalysts described above. The scheme contains four main reaction pathways of anisole transformations, including possible intermediates. The first pathway leads to the formation of benzene (BEN), which quickly transforms into cyclohexane (CHA). Aromatic ring in anisole as well as in BEN can be hydrogenated forming methoxycyclohexane (MCA) – the second pathway. The final product of the third pathway is cyclohexanol (CHL). It is formed via phenol (PHE) and cyclohexanone (CHN) as intermediates, which were found only in trace amounts. The fourth pathway is transesterification, in which anisole transforms into isopropyl phenyl ether (IPE) and then into cyclohexyl isopropyl ether (ICE). In comparison with the schemes of conventional anisole hydrogenation, this scheme contains three main distinctions. First, there is no reaction pathway of methoxycyclohexane to cyclohexanol [50]. Second, cyclohexene and phenol are not considered as final products of anisole conversion, because they were found only in trace amounts [51]. Third, this scheme includes transesterification products, which are not formed in the direct hydrogenation of anisole. The scheme of anisole transformations is based on the kinetic studies shown below. Fig. 6 demonstrates percentage profiles of reaction mixtures, which are approximated using the scheme in Fig. 5. As seen, the kinetics fit the experimental data very well, providing the low root mean square error. If the molar ratio of anisole-to-nickel is ~40/1, then only four stable final products are formed: MCA, CHA, CHL, and ICE. However, if the molar ratio is decreased to ~10/1, the use of Ni_Alum leads to the deoxygenation of MCA (Fig. S3 , see Supplementary information). This result seems to be very important because it shows the high potential of high-loaded nickel-based catalysts in hydrodeoxygenation of non-aromatic compounds under TH conditions. The use of Ni_Alum and Ni_Sil provides a higher anisole conversion, which becomes noticeable before the target temperature is achieved (Fig. 6 a, b). Table 2 shows the calculated rate constants corresponding to the scheme of anisole transformations at 250 °C (Fig. 5). All the constants were calculated using the quasi-first order kinetic model. As mentioned above, the reaction mixtures contained only traces of PHE and CHN; therefore, k4 describes the direct transformation of anisole into CHL. Note also that IPE was an intermediate only over Ni_Sil; therefore, the corresponding rate constant k5 was calculated only for this catalyst. In contrast, over the other catalysts, the conversion of anisole is described as a direct transformation into ICE, with the rate constant k6. Table 2 shows that transesterification is the rate-limiting stage for the fourth reaction pathway, whereas the reduction of the aromatic ring is significantly faster. Thus, k5 calculated for Ni_Sil should be comparable with k6 for transformations over other catalysts. The constants k2, k4, as well as k5, calculated for Ni_Sil are higher than those calculated for the other catalysts. It demonstrates the lability of the O-CH3 bond and the effective reduction of BEN into CHA. This fact can be explained by a combination of such properties of Ni_Sil as a sufficiently developed specific surface, the availability of metal Ni centers, and a high concentration of acid sites, especially the strong ones (Table 1). We believe that namely the strong acid centers determine the rate of transformation via the third route. Nevertheless, the highest total rate constant kΣ=k1 + k3 + k4 + k6 (k5 for the Ni_Sil catalyst) of anisole conversion is observed in the experiments with Ni_Alum, which has the highest Ni0 surface and total acidity. This catalyst demonstrates the superior results in anisole transformations into MCA and BEN. The pathway to BEN seems to be especially important for practice because of the crucial role of deoxygenation in biomass conversion. We also calculated TOF for anisole conversion (Table 2), where the CO uptake data were used as the concentration of active metal centers. The highest TOF was observed for the Ni_Sil catalyst. This catalyst has the highest rate constant k4 for the third route, which correlates with the highest content of acid centers. However, in our opinion, it is not quite correct to normalize the rate constants to the content of acid centers or surface nickel atoms, due to the lack of knowledge about the mechanism of catalytic transformations, as well as due to the lack of understanding about the nature of active centers in this process. Therefore, the given TOF values are calculated in the approximation that the active center is the metal phase. Acid centers also affect the reaction rate, but it is difficult to estimate the number of active acid centers directly for this process so we limited ourselves to an active metal surface for calculating TOF. At 250 °C, Ni_Zirc and Ni_Tit do not demonstrate as high performance in anisole TH as Ni_Sil and Ni_Alum do (Fig. 6 c, d). The anisole conversions over Ni_Zirc and Ni_Tit are close and after 180 min achieves 72 % and 71 %, respectively. The reaction mixtures contain methoxycyclohexane as the main product and lower amounts of cyclohexanol. Ni_Zirc also provides the formation of cyclohexane, which increases the selectivity toward HDO to 20 %. In the case of Ni_Tit, the selectivity toward HDO is only 13 %. The selectivity for HDA in both experiments is in the range of 93–95 %. The decrease in the anisole-to-nickel ratio from ~40/1 to ~10/1 intensifies the formation of HDO ( Table 3 and Fig. S3). Ni_Zirc demonstrates the best performance, producing 37 % of oxygen-free products. The selectivity toward HDO for Ni_Alum remains only 30 % when the anisole conversion achieves 60 %. However, after 3 h, it increases to 42 % because MCA transforms into CHA (Fig. S3). In the experiment with Ni_Sil, the final reaction mixture contains only 28 % of BEN and CHA. However, this catalyst demonstrates the superior results in the O-CH3 bond cleavage with the formation of CHL, which is not considered as HDO in our case. We assume that the high reaction rate of this process explains a comparatively low HDO selectivity in the presence of Ni_Sil. The HDA selectivity in all cases exceeds 92 %. The literature data show a correlation between the number of acid cites [10,11], a size of nickel domains [12,13], and an HDO selectivity. In our study, Ni_Alum and Ni_Sil demonstrate promising results in the C-O bond cleavage in anisole. At the same time, Ni_Alum has the smallest Ni crystallites and the highest concentration of acid sites. Thus, the comparatively high activity of Ni_Alum in HDO can be explained in the same terms. It was demonstrated in our previous studies that the Raney® catalyst containing ~90 % of nickel demonstrated a noticeable activity in the TH at a relatively low temperature of 150 °C [24,52]. Obviously, the high catalytic activity at low temperatures is the indisputable advantage; therefore, high-loaded nickel catalysts prepared by the original SAS coprecipitation method in this work were also tested at 150 °C. Moreover, in the experiments at 250 °C, TH occurred under supercritical conditions, while at 150 °C, the transformations proceeded mostly in the liquid phase. This can significantly affect the activity of the H-donor of alcohols and the kinetics of TH. In order to get representative kinetic data, the amount of the catalyst was increased from 0.12 g to 0.43 g. Fig. 7 shows the kinetics of anisole and reaction products in the experiments with Ni_Sil and Ni_Alum. As seen, the conversion of anisole after 240 min achieves 31 % and 22 % for Ni_Sil and Ni_Alum, respectively. MCA, BEN, and CHA are the main products in both cases, which shows that HDA and HDO proceed in parallel. Similar results were also obtained in early works [10,11]. The HDO selectivity at a 20 % conversion is 45 % for Ni_Sil and 25 % for Ni_Alum (Table 3). The higher selectivities are observed for HDA, which achieve 70 % and 75 %. In contrast to the Ni_Sil and Ni_Alum catalysts, Ni_Zirc demonstrates a low conversion of anisole – only 5 % after 4 h at 150 °C. In the experiment with Ni_Tit, no conversion was observed at all (the data are not shown). We suppose that the HDO selectivity of Ni_Sil at 150 °C is higher than that at 250 °C because of low conversion of anisole. Our data, obtained at 250 °C, show that the HDO selectivity remains high when the anisole conversion is low. This is mainly due to the formation of benzene, the concentration of which quickly achieves a relatively high value. We suppose that the same patterns are typical at 150 °C; therefore, the HDO selectivity will decrease at higher anisole conversion. The calculated rate constants corresponding to the scheme of anisole transformations at 150 °C (Fig. 5) are given in Table 4. At this temperature, the rate constant k1 is close to k3 for Ni_Sil, which increases the HDO selectivity to 45 %. At the same time, the ratio of k1 to k3 for Ni_Alum at 150 °С and 250 °С remains almost constant, which indicates that the change in temperature does not affect the selectivity for this catalyst and, accordingly, the HDO selectivity also practically does not change. As seen from Table 4, Ni_Sil demonstrates higher activity at 150 °C, whereas Ni_Alum is more active at 250 °C. The most probable explanation of this fact is the partial oxidation of the samples. Indeed, the Ni_Alum sample has a greater dispersion and, accordingly, is more susceptible to oxidation. To the contrary, the Ni_Sil sample is more resistant to oxygen because it is less dispersed and thus its oxidation is not so active. At a temperature of 250 °C, the catalysts are reactivated, whereas at a lower temperature (150 °C), they are not. This assumption is also confirmed by the fact that the conversion of anisole at the zero point (time to reach a temperature of 250 °C) is higher for the Ni_Sil catalyst than that for the Ni_Alum catalyst. Thus, the high-loaded Ni-based catalysts, which were prepared by the original SAS coprecipitation method, demonstrate a high potential in the TH of anisole. It has been shown that the acidity and the mean crystallite size of the catalysts significantly affect the transformations of anisole and intermediate products. In this way, the adjustment of the catalyst properties during the preparation procedure is very important. The use of the original preparation method seems to be a very promising tool for controlling the catalyst properties and activity. This method allows one to vary the metal content from 0 % to 100 wt%, to use various supports (almost without changing the preparation procedure), and to control morphological and textural properties of the catalysts. 4 Conclusions Thus, the high-loaded Ni-based catalysts prepared by the original SAS coprecipitation method can demonstrate an excellent performance in TH of anisole under supercritical conditions. The Ni_Sil and Ni_Alum catalysts show a 100 % conversion of anisole after 3 h at 250 °C at the substrate-to-nickel molar ratio ~40/1. The significant influence of the supports on both the catalyst structure and activity has also been demonstrated. It has been found that a strong metal-support interaction between alumina and NiO nanoparticles hinders the reduction of nickel oxide. At the same time, the reduced Ni_Alum catalyst has the smallest Ni0 domains and a developed surface area, which result in the highest rate constant of anisole TH and HDO selectivity (42 %). The Ni_Sil and Ni_Alum catalysts also have the superior number of acid centers, which can explain the high lability of C-O bonds in TH over these catalysts. All synthesized catalysts (except for Ni_Zirc and Ni-Tit at 150 °C) demonstrate a significant activity in HDA, which exceed 89 % and 70 % at 250 °C and 150 °C, respectively. coredata.dc:description: Transfer hydrogenation of anisole in 2-PrOH has been studied as a model reaction for lignocellulose processing. The reaction was studied over high-loaded Ni-based catalysts synthesized via supercritical antisolvent precipitation of a Ni precursor and sols of four oxides: Al2O3, SiO2, TiO2, and ZrO2. It was demonstrated that the oxide support significantly affects the structure of the catalysts, their activity, and selectivity. The best performance in the transfer hydrodeoxygenation of anisole was shown by Ni supported on alumina at 250 °C, which was explained by the highest dispersion of Ni0 particles in this catalyst and by the highest concentration of acid centers.
coredata.dc:title: High-loaded Ni-based catalysts obtained via supercritical antisolvent coprecipitation in transfer hydrogenation of anisole: Influence of the support
